details.description: Wildlife protection for species, finding out if you need a licence to kill, disturb or move particular animals, birds or fish
details.body:
The way you manage pests and wildlife on your land depends on whether the species is protected under wildlife legislation or not. You may need to get a licence to kill, remove or disturb certain species.

The laws around wildlife protection are different in England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales.

If particular species of birds or animals are legally protected, you may need to get a licence to cull them or to disturb their habitats. You’ll usually need to have a good reason (eg they’re attacking your crops or causing a public health problem).

Contact the relevant organisation in your area to find out which species are protected and what you can and can’t do.

England

Contact Wildlife Management and Licensing at Natural England:

  • for advice on dealing with birds and animals on your land
  • to get a licence if necessary

Wildlife Management and Licensing

wildlife@naturalengland.org.uk
0845 6014523

If you suspect an animal or bird has been poisoned, report it to the Wildlife Incident Investigation Scheme.

Wildlife Incident Investigation Scheme

0800 321600 (freephone)

Northern Ireland

You’ll need a licence to:

  • remove bats from your building or disturb their habitat for development work
  • kill or move certain birds, or take their eggs
  • keep or breed some birds of prey

Download licence forms or apply for licences online to the Biodiversity Unit, Northern Ireland Environment Agency. You can also get advice on related topics, such as using rat poison on your land or photographing wildlife.

Biodiversity Unit

028 9056 9605

Scotland

Find out your legal responsibilities if you encounter wildlife as part of your job (eg as a developer, land manager or researcher) or as a member of the public.

Scottish Natural Heritage also has information on activities that need a licence and how you can apply for one.

Scottish Natural Heritage

www.snh.org.uk
enquiries@snh.gov.uk
01463 725 000

Wales

If moles are causing damage or harm to agricultural land (eg damaging plant growth or grass-cutting machinery), you can only control them by trapping them or gassing them using aluminium phosphide.

For advice on managing other wildlife, eg badgers, on your land, contact the Welsh Assembly Government.

Welsh Assembly Government

0300 062 2297
0300 062 2290
0300 062 2241
